Hindi ko rin alam kung bakit ko pinanood 'tong Hayop Ka! ni Avid Liongoren, siguro dahil curious ako sa "unang Pinoy adult animation" sa Netflix. Pero matapos ang isang oras at labinlimang minuto, isa lang ang masasabi ko: hindi benta ang kalibugan ng mga hayop.Yes, maganda ang animation. Hindi maitatangging pulido, colorful, at may effort ang mga animators. Halatang pinag-isipan nila yung detalye ng "animal version ng Pilipinas." Witty yung names ng lugar, makulay ang background, at minsan may mga visual gags na effective. Pero sayang, kasi lahat ng ganda, tinabunan ng isang script na parang binunot sa pinakababa ng basura ng Philippine showbiz.Nakakabwisit yung sobrang sexualization ng mga karakter. Oo, satire daw. Oo, gusto raw magpatawa gamit ang bold jokes. Pero ang kinalabasan, parang hyper-sexualized telenovela na hindi malaman kung seryoso ba siyang commentary sa class divide o gusto lang niyang gawing "bomba cartoon" si Nimfa. May mga lewd puns na hindi nakakatawa, may mga eksena na parang lowbrow radio drama, at may ending pa na pinilit gawing redemption arc gamit ang "nice guy" trope. Ang suffocating din ng casual misogyny na parang diniktahan kang kamuhian si Nimfa for making choices na, in reality, rooted sa kahirapan niya.Ang daming Pinoy teleserye clich√©s dito. Mayaman vs. mahirap, kabit-kabit, pangarap makaahon sa hirap, tapos puro moralizing sa dulo. Kung satire nga talaga, bakit parang mas kinampihan pa ang mga luma at problematikong values? Parang instead of poking fun at them, nire-recycle lang nila.Props lang sa animators! Sila lang talaga yung nagdala ng pelikula. Hindi nila kasalanan na yung script ay puno ng infidelity, sexism, at macho bullshit na hindi na dapat sinusubo pa sa audience. Sa totoo lang, mas deserve nilang bigyan ng proyekto na mas meaningful at hindi ganitong caricature ng lahat ng maling bagay sa local entertainment industry.TLDR: Kung gusto mong makita kung ano ang hitsura ng Zootopia kung ginawa siyang panghapon na teleserye na puno ng sabaw na kabitan, eto na 'yon. Pero kung meaningful satire ang hanap mo, huwag ka na mag-aksaya ng oras.

The first time I watched Hayop Ka!, I honestly just saw it as a bastos movie, parang puro kabastusan lang HAHA. But upon rewatching it, I realized the concept is actually liberating and surprisingly close to reality. Its vibrancy and exaggerated humor felt more like satire‚Äîa playful but biting critique of how consumerism shapes the world we live in.Through a realist lens, the film mirrors the everyday struggles of many Filipinos, though wrapped in an animated, comedic package. The stark contrast between the rich and the poor was a constant theme. How privilege dictates not only opportunities but also relationships. Even love in the film is framed by class and material wealth, showing how affection is often entangled with survival and status.From a Marxist perspective, Nimfa‚Äôs relationships expose how capitalism and consumerism seep into our most intimate desires. Her dissatisfaction with her current boyfriend and her attraction to a wealthier partner may seem superficial at first, but it reflects how the system conditions people to equate love with upward mobility and financial security. The film satirizes how consumer culture commodifies even emotions and human connection, turning them into transactions rather than purely personal bonds.Looking at it through feminist theory naman, my initial impression of Nimfa as "malandi" for wanting more felt unfair. On rewatch, I realized this judgment reflects how women are often shamed for pursuing their desires, especially if those desires break away from traditional expectations. The film suggests that Nimfa‚Äôs choices are not purely personal flaws but rather shaped by the larger forces of patriarchy and capitalism, where women are pressured to chase an ‚Äúideal‚Äù version of love, security, and femininity. It questions why women are criticized for seeking better lives, while men who fail to provide are rarely scrutinized in the same way.In the end, Hayop Ka! may seem chaotic and shallow at first glance, but digging deeper, it becomes a satirical mirror of our society; where class, consumerism, and gender roles intersect to shape even the most personal aspects of life like love and relationships.

I remember all the hype about this back in 2020! Shame it took a course in my fourth/last year of college before I pressed play on this‚Ä¶Anyway, I thought this was effective and authentic. Your way of life and finances really do dictate how you live your life tbh‚Ä¶ the resentment towards each other (Nimfa, a saleslady, belittling his janitor boyfriend) is real; you resent each other because you both cannot lift each other up, yet the system is unfortunately devised in a way that keeps you both down. While it very much feels like something so inspired by films from the late 2010s, its themes held up really well. Five years after its release, I‚Äôve never seen class resentment be so pervasive all over. Watching this in 2025 made me realize that wow, this has been a dilemma for ages. Nimfa resorts to participating as a caller in a radio program, whose misogynist host attacks her for her decisions. However, Nimfa‚Äôs actions were dictated so by her circumstances; you cannot blame someone for doing what they do if they‚Äôre in the margins of society. I really liked how Raffy Tulfo was satirized here. Its ending was a bit too far-fetched, if you watched in 2020. But in a time that is currently very much intent on ‚Äòeating the rich,‚Äô and after Luigi Mangione did what he did, it‚Äôs not far-fetched anymore. Maybe this film was ahead of its time tbh‚Ä¶ Anyway, I was cracking up over several jokes. I particularly liked the scene where Nimfa‚Äôs workmate was revealed to be fucking Nimfa‚Äôs boyfriend üòÇ just insane throughout.I just didn‚Äôt really like the abundance of sexual jokes‚Ä¶ it felt incredibly juvenile. If you get off on making animals freaky, then please go all the way, instead of showing them moaning so sexually and then revealing they‚Äôre just having a foodgasm. This was hailed as a boundary-pushing film, but all I got was a work that felt too afraid to be unabashedly themselves. You‚Äôd get the respect you crave if you own the furry freak in you. Nonetheless though, I think it‚Äôs a good critique on the system that pits the poor against each other! It aged well.

Unang una, animation-wise, ang ganda. Ang effort ng mga animator may detail, style, at fluidity. Pero doon na nagkaproblema sa kwento. Sadly, the plot just didn‚Äôt hold up. Kahit gaano pa kaganda ang animation, kung paulit-ulit pa rin ang narrative themes, walang bago at walang depth hindi na rin kayang isalba ng visuals even though I'm a sucker for visuals, masarap sa mata kaso ang hirap i-ignore 'yung nilalangaw na plot.I'm not expecting some Pixar story plotline pero it doesn't hurt to criticize kung paano nila in-execute.Usual tropes na naman: cheating, class divide, misogyny, poverty porn, and outdated character stereotypes. Nakakapagod na panoorin kasi parang wala ng bagong sinasabi. Instead of elevating the story with the animation, parang mas lalo lang na-highlight kung gaano kababaw at problematic ‚Äòyung plot. Even the dialogues felt off awkward, minsan cringey, minsan tone-deaf. Imbes na ma-immerse ka sa kwento, nadidistract ka sa kung gaano ka unnatural pakinggan ng mga linya. Sayang. Ang ganda ng animation, pero nasayang sa isang plot na hindi masyadong pinag-isipan or nag-stick sa classic tropes ng Philippine media. Still, major kudos to the animators, sana well-compensated at recognized sila with the artistry they've shown.

I really wish I could figure out just why this is rated so low on Letterboxd. If ever there was a movie I wanted to have a conversation about, this is it, because I fail to see why this really fun, slightly dramatic, but overall interesting slice of life is so universally panned. I think it goes without saying to praise the animation in Hayop-ka - it‚Äôs smooth and moves fluidly, it leaves itself open for some really impressive expressions and powerful images in scenes. The backgrounds are picturesque, and create a very vivid feeling of what this version of the Philippines is like: lively, energetic, maybe a little crowded but full of interesting characters. I think it‚Äôs worth mentioning, too, how good these backgrounds are at communicating different regions: the scenic beach near the luxury cabin, the quiet village that‚Äôs contrasted by its tight knit sense of community, both contrasted against the usual setting of the city. And while I‚Äôve seen in other reviews that people find the innuendos in the background jokes to be tacky or in poor taste, I actually found that not only were a lot of them funny, but I think it creates a tangible sense of a world populated by Anthro animals more than other media tends to. I think sex is a pretty natural human experience, and a lot of real life marketing sells sex very transparently, and lots of mainstream Anthro animation doesn‚Äôt address that. It‚Äôs outside the ratings for films like Zootopia and Sing, and sexuality is so central a focus of a story like Beastars that normalizing it would kind of destroy its themes. And I think that perhaps Hayop-Ka‚Äôs depiction of sexuality in this world is one of its greatest strengths. Which, I guess, is interesting, because it seems like part of the negative backlash to Hayop-Ka is the accusation that is perverse or obscene for its sexual nature. Which seems‚Ä¶ weird to me. The sex isn‚Äôt explicit in it, and Nimpha is only pictured having sex in the film once. The films setting is steeped in sexuality: sexuality is marketed on every sign on every street, and Nimpha‚Äôs motivation is mostly based around sex,But it doesn‚Äôt feel that weird I guess? It‚Äôs a story about an adult woman making adult choices, and the use of sexuality is only out of place because it‚Äôs animation - but there‚Äôs a lot of animated stories that are a lot more sexual than this. And like I said, I think the sexuality makes the plot kind of interesting. By the third act, the novelty of animal-sex-world kinda dies off, and the film isn‚Äôt really about that, as it becomes a series of Nimpha making increasingly more destructive decisions with basically everyone involved in her life. But by that point in the film, I had already been hooked in, and I was interested in what would happen to Nimpha. The positive sexual expression was a great hook for the first act, and moving into the second and third, I cared enough about the established characters enough to weigh the morality of their decisions in my head. Nimpha does something objectively bad to Roger, but it is understandable that she wants to better herself, and Roger‚Äôs tendency towards violence make him seem like a less dependable partner. But Inigo‚Äôs a literal villain, and if him talking about partnering with Elon musk didn‚Äôt telegraph that enough, he is a character who openly talks about working with the Filipino president to keep wages down. When Nimpha confronts her family in the third act, she‚Äôs objectively wrong, but I can‚Äôt really be mad at her, because it‚Äôs a realistic emotional outburst. I‚Äôve watched a lot of stories about bad people who misuse sexuality in their lives. And I‚Äôll never claim that Hayop-Ka - an animated parody of soap operas meant to poke fun at infidelity - is even half as weighty as T√°r or Bojack Horseman - heavy commentary about how celebrity is used to leverage power. But, I do file this movie in a similar place in my head. Watching a not great person try to be better and trying to figure out why things are so messy. And frankly!!! I actually adore the ending for that. Because Nimfa does fuck up, she does do bad things, but people in her life do bad things back to her. And in the end the best thing Nimfa can do is just‚Ä¶ walk away. Start a new life. And she does and I think that‚Äôs beautiful. I do think it‚Äôs worth mentioning the sexist overtones in the climax of the movie - when Nimfa calls the radio station. A reference to an unfortunately very real trend of men berating women for doing anything other than serving whatever man is already present in her life. I feel like part of the negative reception of Hayop Ka is that people read this as him being right but like‚Ä¶ no?? He‚Äôs just not? Maybe it‚Äôs my prior knowledge making me biased against a man in a recording booth telling a woman how to live her life, but in that moment I think it‚Äôs Nimfa‚Äôs last attempt to rely on men, and her faith in it is shattered when she talks to Inigo again. Because yeah - don‚Äôt know if you notice - she can‚Äôt even try to follow that bull‚Äôs advice, because she never gets a chance to come clean to Inigo if she wanted to. And I think that Nimfa marching for maternity leave and raising her child on her own with her family shows that Nimfa‚Äôs life isn‚Äôt going to revolve around the approval of men anymore. It‚Äôs possible that‚Äôs cope: that this is a sexist message I‚Äôm jumping through hoops to spin in a way that empowers the protagonist in the end. But I dunno, I kinda constructed that reading without thinking about it. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs that much of a stretch.I‚Äôm going to be coming back to Hayop-Ka at some point, for sure. It‚Äôs filed in my brain alongside a lot of my favorite depictions of every day life in an animal world. It‚Äôs a little melodramatic, but I do think that the depiction of Nimfa, and how her story ends, does tell a good, grounded story. I think I, a bunny, am always going to be happy with a film that I start and whose title very loudly says to me,‚ÄúYou‚Äôre an animal‚Äù

I found it to be a bit too melodramatic for my taste, and while I suppose you can say it is because of it being a satire on the way the tropes in Filipino media act, but even then I feel like it missed the ball sometimes. Sometimes it does good, I like the end credits of our main character learning to not be as much of a piece of shit, but something about it urks me, you know? Another person had mentioned how sort of misogynistic this movie is, and how while sometimes it does good in relation to satirizing the concepts shown, sometimes it just uh...doesn't I guess? It sort of goes well, we were satirizing this but now we mean it genuinely I suppose. This isn't me being against characters who are shitty people like the way it is in this movie, I love bad people doing awful things to each other, maybe its the cheating aspect or the over exaggeration but it comes off as more of a smear against women who want more in life. I can't blame our main character to want to be living comfortably, she works a dead end job and wants to be happy, I'm not defending her, by any stretch of the imagination, fuck her, but I feel this aura of sinister intentions. As a whole this movie is beautiful when it comes to animation, but the story is overly dramatic to the point of it being more stupid than anything else, and while the fact it is a satire saves it sometimes, other times it really isn't satirical and just dumb. Go watch it though just for the animation and some of the jokes. Maybe just once if you can't stand stupidity in your movies, but it is worth the watch.
